quote: (indicating the star     map)    -- the Dominion has solidified its    hold on the Kalandra Sector.    They're trying to establish a    supply line running through    Betazoid space into the Argolis    Cluster.
If they succeed, they would be    able to launch an attack on    Vulcan.
Starfleet's going to try to cut    them off near the Tibor Nebula.    The Seventh Fleet will be engaging    the enemy in the morning.
The Seventh Fleet is still at half-   strength. They took heavy losses    at Sybaron.
We'll just have to hope they can    get the job done.        On a happier note, I do have a bit    of good news.
That's a welcome change.
The Romulans have forced the    Dominion to retreat from the    Bolian System.
That is good news. The question    is, will the Romulans be willing    to leave Bolarus after the war's    over?
Once they capture territory, they    rarely give it up.
Right now, we need to concentrate    on beating the Dominion. We'll    worry about the Romulans later.
As some of you already know, Major    Kira, Jake and I will be leaving    for Bajor at twenty-two hundred.
There's a war on -- this is no    time for a vacation.
The archaeologists excavating    B'hala have found something they    want the Emissary to see.
We'll be back tomorrow night.        That's all, people.
"Will the Romulans leave Bolarus?"    You love to bring up the worst-   case scenario in these meetings,    don't you?
Somebody has to.
Besides, everyone expects me to be    dour and suspicious. I don't like    to disappoint them.
If they only knew the real you.
That is the real me.        At least as far as everyone else    is concerned.
I can't tell you how pleased we    are by your visit, Emissary.
I'm happy to be here, Ranjen.
There's no need to keep calling me    "Ranjen." I'm a simple monk. My    order is quite informal.
You've certainly been busy. The    last time I visited these ruins,    none of these tunnels had been cut    yet.
It's been a great deal of work,    but we do it gladly. Excavating    the Holy City is a privilege. Our    efforts are an expression of our   faith in the Prophets... and in    the Emissary.
Something wrong, Jake?
No. It's just that Dad seems to    be taking his role as the Emissary    very seriously these days.
You say that like you think it's    a bad thing.
You have to admit, it's a long way    to come to look at some old ruins.
They've found what might be an    important religious artifact in    these "old ruins."
I hope so.    (re: the PADD in his     hand)    Otherwise I won't have much of a    story.
Try to look like you're enjoying    yourself. Your father needs this.    It's good for him not to have to    worry about the Dominion for a few    hours.
Don't let the bats bother you.
Don't worry, they rarely bite.
(still scanning the     ceiling)    Rarely?
We're directly below the Temple of    B'hala. These walls predate the    ancient city by ten thousand    years.
Who built this place?
We don't know much about the    original inhabitants, but it    appears they abandoned this site    some twenty-five thousand years    ago. Over time, sediment buried    the ruins.
And then B'hala was built on top    of them.
Precisely.
In here...
It's over thirty thousand years old...
These inscriptions, they look    similar to ancient Bajoran, but I    can't quite make them out.
Until recently, we couldn't    either. But we've been able to    piece together some rudimentary    translations.
The syntax is unusual, but all    forms of Bajoran share certain    root-ideograms.       You may recognize this one.
Welcome...
Here's where it gets   interesting...
I see you recognize it.
I don't.
It says... Welcome, Emissary.
Now you know why I asked you here.
The Sisko has come.
The circle is complete.
The Reckoning must begin.
The Reckoning?
Much will depend on the Sisko.
He is corporeal.
Limited.
He is the Sisko. He will not   waver.
He is of Bajor.
He will bring the Reckoning.
What is it you expect of me?
It will be the end...
Or the beginning.
I don't understand.
The Sisko will know.
Dad, are you okay?
The Prophets... they were here.   They spoke to me.
You had a vision, Emissary. We   saw nothing.
What did they say to you?
They mentioned a "Reckoning."       Is that part of some prophecy?
Not one that I know of.
Dad, I think we should go now.
It's all right, Jake. We'll be   leaving soon.
I need to know what these    inscriptions say...
I wish we could translate them    more quickly, but we don't have    the resources.
Fortunately, we do.
I had a pretty good idea what this    was the minute I laid eyes on it.        This confirms it.
It's a slab of stone with some    writing on it.
Dax.
What do you want me to say,    Benjamin?
I'm not picking up any residual    energy readings, certainly nothing    that would explain how it threw    you across a room.
I want you to translate the   inscriptions.
I was afraid you were going to say    that.
The Ranjen's translation program.    It's not complete, but at least    it's a start.        Good luck.
"Coming to Services?" "It's about    to start." Etc.
Ops to Sisko.
Go ahead.
We just received a communication    from Bajor. Kai Winn is on her    way to the station.
Welcome to Deep Space Nine, your    eminence.
Thank you, Emissary.
What brings you to the station?
I should think that would be    clear.
You removed an artifact from an    archaeological site without    consulting the Vedek Assembly.
I meant no disrespect.

You can understand that we would    be sensitive to such matters.    During the Occupation, the    Cardassians plundered Bajor's    historical treasures as if it were    their right. I never imagined    that you would behave in the same    manner.
I assure you the artifact will be    returned as soon as I've finished    studying it.
I was not aware that you had    expertise in Bajoran history.
I don't.
Then why not leave the artifact in    the hands of those who do? There    are scholars on Bajor who've    devoted their lives to the study    of such things.
I understand. But I brought it    here because I believe that's what    the Prophets want.
I see. I take it this has    something to do with your...    "vision."
Exactly.
Forgive me.        I didn't realize that the Prophets    told you to bring the relic here.
They didn't. Not in so many    words.
I see. Then what, exactly, did    they say?
It's difficult to explain. The    Prophets aren't always clear.
Since they've never spoken to me,    I'll have to take your word for it.
All I know is that, for now, it    belongs here.
Who am I to argue with the    Emissary of the Prophets?
She contacted Starfleet and lodged    a formal protest.
Is that why Admiral Ross wanted to    talk to you?
So how'd it go?
He told me to stop meddling in    Bajoran affairs and return the    damn tablet.

You know how Starfleet feels about    "this Emissary thing." It makes    them very uncomfortable that    you've allowed the Bajorans to    view you as a religious icon.        It used to make you uncomfortable,    too.
Not anymore.        I guess the Prophets have spoken    to me too many times.
I remember when you used to call    them "Wormhole Aliens."

Wormhole Aliens or Prophets -- it    doesn't really matter. The fact    is, they exist outside of time,    and over the centuries, they've    given the Bajorans glimpses of the    future.        Glimpses that the Bajorans wrote    down to help guide succeeding    generations.
(continuing, re: the     tablet)    If whatever's written here can    help me avoid mistakes and make    the right decisions, I'd be a fool    to ignore it.
Fair enough. But if you don't    mind, I'm going to keep thinking    of them as Wormhole Aliens.

All I know is that they have a    relationship with Bajor that    stretches back thousands of years.    They care about what happens to    the Bajorans. They proved that    when they kept the Dominion fleet    from coming through the wormhole.
Didn't you have to talk them into    it? Didn't they say they were    going to exact some kind of    "penance" for helping you?

Yes, but they listened. They    saved Bajor and the rest of the    Alpha Quadrant.. And now they're    asking me for something in return.    I don't know what it is yet, and    I'm not going to return the tablet    until I do. It's the key. I can    feel it.
I hope you're wrong about that,    Benjamin...
What've you got?
The computer just translated part    of the inscription. Here it is in    modern Bajoran.
"The time of Reckoning is at hand.    The Prophets will weep, and their    sorrow will consume... "    (the rest stops him in     his tracks)   "... the Gateway to the Temple."
Tell me I'm wrong, but isn't the    Gateway to the Temple... Deep    Space Nine?
-- I'm only telling you what the    translation said. I did not say    I believed it.
Well, I'm not worried. If you    look hard enough, you can find a    Bajoran Prophecy for just about    anything. The Ancient Texts are    a tangle of vague contradictions.
This one is anything but vague.    And Bajoran Prophecies have an odd    way of coming true.
Don't tell me you believe in this    stuff, too?
Odo believes in preparing for the    worst.
True.
He's as bad as the Bajorans.    (looking around the     quiet bar with dismay)    Business hasn't been this slow    since the Dominion was here.
You know, I feel it's my civic    duty to do something about all    this doom and gloom. That's why    I want you all to know that I've    extended Happy Hour.
Extended it?
From now on, every hour is Happy    Hour.        At least, until business picks up.
Eat, drink and be merry.
For tomorrow we die.
What does the captain say about    all this?
He's reserving judgement until the    computer's finished the    translation.
Who knows, maybe the rest of the    tablet says go to Quark's for    Happy Hour.
I like the way you think, doctor.
This is ridiculous. Nothing's    going to happen. Someday we're    going to look back at this and    laugh.
That's the third time in the last    ten minutes.
Still no incoming ships.
Well something's making the    wormhole do that.
How did that Prophecy go again... ?
You know, you really don't have to    do this.
What?
Stay here and watch me eat.
I don't mind. In fact, I rather   enjoy it.    (off her questioning     look)    You eat with such gusto.        Most of the time.
Not today.        I just wish we knew more about the    Reckoning. It'd give us a better    idea of what the Prophets want    from us.
It seems to me that if the    Prophets want the Bajoran people    to follow a given path, they    should provide more specific    directions.
It doesn't work that way.
Maybe it should.
The Kai would say you lacked    faith.
And you would agree.
I don't know how people make it    through the day without it.
We manage. Besides, I do have    faith in some things.
Such as?
You.
I'll try not to disappoint you.
No doubt you've heard the latest    news from Bajor.
About the flooding in Rakantha    Province, yes.
There was also an earthquake in    the Kendra Valley last night.    This morning a tornado struck    Tamulna --
Our sensors indicate Bajor's being    affected by the instability in the    wormhole.
How comforting. Tell me, do your    sensors have an explanation for    the instability itself?
No.
Then I'll give you one. You've    angered the Prophets by taking the    tablet from Bajor. As the    spiritual leader of the Bajoran    people, I'm asking you to return    it.
And as Emissary of the Prophets,    I'm asking you to give me more    time to study it.         I believe it's the will of the    Prophets.
I disagree.
This is a formal request from the    First Minister that you turn over    the relic to me.
You must've been very persuasive.    This is the first time you and    Shakaar have agreed on anything.
If you deny his request, I promise    you it will damage relations    between Bajor and the Federation.
The tablet will be on its way to    Bajor on the morning transport.
As will I.
You're sending it back?       I was just starting to have fun.
You're not off the hook, old man.    I still want those inscriptions    translated.
I can work off the holo-recordings    I took yesterday.
Have you made any more progress?        Good news or bad?
That depends.
On what?
What this ideogram means. The    computer's giving me two    possibilities.
Let's hear them.
During the Reckoning, the Bajorans    are either going to "suffer    horribly," or... "eat fruit."
Eat fruit?
Given the tone of the rest of the    inscriptions, I'd bet on the    horrible suffering.
What else have you got?
You're going to love this, it's    about you.
It says that once the "Reckoning    begins, the Emissary will" --
Go on.
I was hoping you'd tell me. The    rest of the inscription is    damaged.
That figures.
I wish the wormhole would stop    doing that.
Me, too.        Keep at it, old man.
Just do me one favor.        If you talk to the Prophets again,    ask them for a dictionary.
I'll see what I can do.
Captain, I've got a message for    you from General Martok.
Go ahead.
He's dispatched three squadrons of    Klingon attack cruisers to bolster    the defense perimeter around the    Dorala System.
Good. I just hope they can hold    out until Starfleet can send    reinforcements.
The Klingons will hold out.    Martok will see to that.
Long day?
They keep getting longer.
You'll feel better in the morning.
Once the Kai is off the station.
I know she's the spiritual leader    of millions of Bajorans, but she's    not an easy woman to like.
If it's any comfort, I don't think    she likes you, either.
I've known that for a while.        Maybe I should've consulted her    before I brought the artifact up    to the station.
She would've tried to stop you.
I guess that's why I didn't ask    her.

In a way, I feel sorry for her.    She spends her whole life in the    service of the Prophets. And then    one day, after all the years of    personal sacrifice and commitment,    she's given her reward. She's    elected Kai. It should've been    the greatest moment of her life.
(seeing where Kira is     going)    But my being Emissary spoiled it    for her.

The Kai has always been the    spiritual leader of Bajor. But    Winn has to share that role with    you. And what makes matters worse    is you're an outsider -- a non-   Bajoran. That's something she'll    never forgive you for.
I guess that's why she's made such   an issue out of this whole thing.
She's jealous of you and of your   relationship with the Prophets.       To be honest, I'm a little envious   myself.
Why?
You speak with the Prophets. They   listen to you. It's a rare gift.
It's nothing I asked for.
I suppose that's why I don't   resent you. But the Kai does.
I'll keep that in mind.
Is something wrong, Eminence?
What makes you say that, child?
You look troubled.
Not at all. I'm quite relieved   that the Emissary has decided to    do the right thing.
You didn't leave him much choice,    did you?

I suppose you think I enjoyed    forcing his hand. I assure you I    didn't. I wish the situation    could have been resolved more    amicably.        Perhaps the next time we have a    disagreement, he will consider my    wishes more thoughtfully.
The next time?        Are you anticipating more   "disagreements?"
I merely meant to express my hope    that in the future, we can work    together for the good of Bajor.
Of course. After all, you're on    the same side. Aren't you?
Naturally. We both serve the    Prophets. There is no higher    calling.        Sometimes, I sense you forget    that, child.
When was the last time you went to   the Shrine to pray?
A few days ago.
I see.
I've been busy attending to    station business.
I've found that daily prayer is    indispensable to a fulfilling    spiritual life. Perhaps you    should make time to cultivate your    faith.
I will.
If I'm not mistaken, evening    services are about to begin.
I think so, yes.
Then go, child. You wouldn't want   to be late.
Yes.
Jake-o.
You're up late.
So are you.
What's on your mind?
I don't know. I guess I just    wanted to make sure you're all    right.
I'm fine. Since when did you    become such a worrier?
This Emissary stuff. It scares me    a little.
Jake.

Twice now, twice in one year --    Doctor Bashir's called me down to    the Infirmary to tell me something    was wrong with you. And there you    were, lying unconscious on a bio-   bed, having visions or something.    There was nothing I could do    except stand there... and wonder    if you were ever going to wake up.
I know it wasn't easy.
I don't want it to happen again.
I never asked to be the Emissary.       But for better or worse, that's   what I am.
Why do you always have to be so    damn mysterious?
Answer me! I'm tired of your    riddles. If you need me to do    something, say so.
Let me guess -- you accidentally   knocked it over.
Not exactly.
I didn't think so.
So what did happen?
I just had an uncontrollable   urge... to smash the tablet.
I get those urges all the time.   Of course, I never act on them...       I'm not reading any residual   energy signatures.
That's impossible. Check the   station's internal sensors.
Nothing.
I'm telling you I saw something.
We believe you, captain.
Please Constable, don't patronize   me.
Sisko to Ops. Report.
We just experienced a stationwide    power drain. We are attempting to    determine the source.
Keep me informed.
Aye, Sir.
It could be that the power drain    is related to this energy    discharge you saw.
I'm starting to think the same    thing.
Benjamin -- you're not getting    another urge, are you?
No.        I've done what I needed to do.        I know this is going to sound    strange, but I think the Prophets    wanted me to shatter the tablet.
Try explaining that to Kai Winn.
I can't believe that you'd be so    petty as to destroy the artifact    rather than turn it over to me.
That's not why I did it.
You expect me to believe that the    Prophets wanted you to destroy a    priceless piece of Bajor's    history?
Yes, that's exactly what you have    to believe.
And why would they do that?
I wish I had an answer for you.
I'm sure in time you'll come up    with something.

You and I haven't always seen eye    to eye, but wehave one thing in    common. We both believe the    Prophets have a plan for Bajor.    But sometimes it isn't easy to see    the path they've laid out for us.
Right now, I can't say I know what    they want from me. But I'm    willing to take a leap of faith,    and believe that they're guiding    me. I'm asking you to take that    leap with me.

There's no need for a leap of    faith, Emissary. The Prophets    have made themselves quite clear.    Two-thirds of the Rakantha wheat    harvest has been destroyed by    floods. Earthquakes have    devastated Kendra Province,    leaving hundreds homeless.    Bajorans are suffering because of    you. They're paying the price for    your act of sacrilege.
Odo to Captain Sisko.
Go ahead.
You'd better come down to the    Promenade, Sir.
Is there a problem?
I'll let you be the judge of that.
I think we've found the source of    the power fluctuations.
When I tried to talk to her, she    ignored me.
You... are the Sisko.
Keep your hands off your weapons.     (turning back to face     Kira)    It's a Prophet. Why have you    taken this woman's body?
This vessel is willing. The    Reckoning. It is time.
This "Reckoning." What is it?
The end... or the beginning.
I don't understand.
I await Kosst Amojan.
The Evil One -- a Pah-wraith --    banished from the Celestial    Temple.
You're saying a Pah-wraith will    take corporeal form as well?
The battle will be joined.
This battle -- it's going to take    place here?
Bajor will be reborn.
Shabren's Fifth Prophecy. The    Rebirth...        If the Evil One is destroyed, it    will bring a thousand years of    peace.    (realizing what this     means)    The Golden Age of Bajor.
If it's destroyed?
Who will prevail is not known.
What do you want from me? Am I    supposed to help you in some way?
The Sisko has completed his task.
Forgive me for my blindness.
Prophet, hear me. I am the Kai of    Bajor. I offer myself as your    humble servant..
I await their vessel.
Speak to me. Tell me what I    should do.
We're evacuating.
You can't be serious.
This "battle" could destroy the    station.
Then don't let it be fought here.
I don't have any choice.
Yes, you do. We could flood the    Promenade with chroniton    radiation.
Are you suggesting we kill a    Prophet?
I won't do that.
You don't have to. If we ramp up    the chroniton levels slowly, it'll    give the Wormhole Alien a chance    to leave Kira's body before it's    harmed.
We have everything rigged and    ready to go. Just say the word.
No.
Benjamin.
Deep Space Nine is critical to the    defense of the Federation. We    can't risk allowing it to be    destroyed.

When the Dominion fleet was about    to come through the wormhole, I    asked the Prophets for help. They    gave it to me. Now they're asking    for my help. They need to fight    this battle here, now. I'm not    going to jeopardize my crew, but    I'm not going to stand in the way    of the Prophets, either.
What if the Prophets lose? Are    you willing to sacrifice Kira?
The Prophet said she was willing    to be their instrument.
And you believe that?
I do.
I know how important her faith is    to her. I have no doubt she'd    allow the Prophets to use her as    their instrument.
I'll notify Starfleet that we're    abandoning the station. Begin the    evacuation immediately.
Is this transport full?
There's room.
I'm going to check the Promenade    for stragglers.
Odo...
You should've helped us persuade    the captain to end this.
I had to respect Kira's wishes.
If it were Dax, I'm not sure I    could have done the same.
Just be glad you didn't have to    make that choice.
I hope, for your sake, that the    Prophets are victorious.
They will be.        If Kira has anything to do with    it.
Report.
We expect to be down to a skeleton    crew within the hour.
Very good.
What did Starfleet have to say?
I managed to convince them that we    couldn't afford to defy the Prophets.
They are the only thing keeping    the Dominion from coming through    the wormhole.
True enough. The only problem is,    there's no guarantee the Prophets    will win this battle.
Odo to Sisko.
Go ahead, Constable.
Captain, there's a group of    Bajorans on the Promenade who are    refusing to leave.
Tera dak ihsehelm ran embah...
... de-ram ta-meen...
Tera dak ihsehelm ran embah...
... de-ram ta-MEEN...
The last transports are standing    by.
Eminence.
Emissary.
These people have to leave.
We're offering prayers for the    Prophet's victory.
The Prophets will hear your    prayers wherever you are. It    isn't safe here.
Then why haven't you left,    Emissary? The Prophet said your    task was done.
I'm still captain of this station    and I'm going to do everything in    my power to save it.         Now, are you going to tell these    people to go, or should I?
My children, the Prophets have    heard your prayers. You must go.
Take them to the transports.
Congratulations, Emissary. Thanks    to you, the Prophets' victory is    at hand.
I hope you're right.
Where's your faith, Emissary? You    don't believe that the Evil One    will be victorious, do you?
Rest assured, the Golden Age is    upon us. The Prophets and the    people will be as one. Think of    it. There'll be no need for    Vedeks or Kais... or even    Emissaries.
Kosst Amojan has chosen its    vessel.
Let it begin.
No. Not my son.
Take me instead.
Your Emissary offers himself to   us. His faith wavers.
We must go, Emissary.
Benjamin!
Worf's standing by in Ops -- he    can trigger the chroniton    generator at your command. You    can still end this, Ben.
No, I have to let it play out.
That's your son out there!
You think I don't know that?
The Prophets will protect him.
Ben, they're trying to kill him.
No, they're trying to destroy the   Pah-wraith.
How do you know?
(simply, but with     conviction)   I know.
We've got to get out of here.   According to the sensors, that   energy building up between them   could explode any second.
I'm not going to leave Jake.
Emissary, you must go. Bajor    needs you.
She's right.
Get off the station. Now. That's    an order.
Come, child. We must go.
Go ahead.
Meet me at Airlock Eight. We're    leaving.
Go on ahead. Airlock Eight is to    the right.
Let me help you.
No.
Chroniton levels at thirty-nine   kilanons and climbing...
May the Prophets forgive me...
Jake. Jake.
He'll be laid up for a few days,    but he's going to be all right.
Can I see him?
For a minute.
Dad?
How're you feeling?
Could be worse.
You'll be up and about in no time.
I don't know what to say.
Say you're happy to see me.
You know I am.
Jake, I want to try to explain    what happened -- but I'm not sure    I can.
You don't have to explain.
When the Pah-wraith was inside me,    I could feel its hatred. And I    knew that no matter what, it    couldn't be allowed to win. Even    if it meant I had to die.
You did the right thing.
How was the prayer service?
To tell you the truth, I wasn't    paying that much attention.         I guess I'm still trying to make    sense of everything that happened.
Of all the people on this station,    the Prophet chose me. I don't    know why I deserved that honor.
Maybe that's why you were chosen.    You have faith and humility.
I heard that you told the captain    I was willing to give my life to    serve the Prophets. I appreciate    that you respect my beliefs.
Just the same, I wouldn't have    minded if the Prophets had chosen    someone else.
I have to go. I'll drop by    Security after I take the Kai to    her shuttle.
The Emissary couldn't escort me    himself?
He's with his son.
I would've thought he'd want to thank me.
For what?
I prevented the destruction of    this station. I saved the    Emissary's life and the life of    his son.
Don't pretend you did it for the    captain.
I did it for Bajor. If you    haven't heard, the floodwaters    have receded and the earthquakes    have stopped.
And you're going to take the    credit for that?
I take it as a sign that I did the    right thing.

You defied the will of the    Prophets. And you did it because    you couldn't stand the fact that    a human, an infidel, had a    stronger faith than you. The    Emissary was willing to sacrifice    his own son to serve the Prophets.
My faith is as pure as the    Emissary's.
I think you're confusing faith    with ambition.
I'm not confusing anything, child,    you are. The Prophets chose you    as their instrument, that doesn't    mean you can speak for them.
Because of your interference,    the Reckoning was stopped. The    Evil still exists. And I'm not    sure even the Prophets know what    that means for Bajor.
